title: Eli Lilly snaps up Watertown biotech in $2.4 billion deal
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Eli Lilly is acquiring Watertown-based Orna Therapeutics for $2.4 billion to boost its genetic medicines portfolio.
Orna Therapeutics specializes in circular RNA technology to enable immune cells to fight diseases within the body.
The acquisition marks Eli Lilly's continued investment in Massachusetts biotech, following purchases of Scorpion and Verve Therapeutics.

title: Boston man paroled after serving 16 years of life sentence for fatal stabbing outside bar
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Corey Patterson, convicted for a 2009 stabbing, was paroled after serving 16 years of a life sentence.
Massachusetts Parole Board cited Patterson's sobriety, education, and community efforts in their parole decision.
Parole conditions include electronic monitoring, curfew, no contact with the victim's family, and counseling.

title: ‘You’re going to feel the pain’: Kurt Warner’s advice to Drake Maye after losing Super Bowl LX
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Kurt Warner discussed Patriots quarterback Drake Maye processing the Super Bowl LX loss after a successful season.
The Patriots lost Super Bowl LX to the Seahawks 29-13 after unexpected success following consecutive 4-13 seasons.
Warner emphasized that head coach Mike Vrabel offers valuable perspective as the Patriots continue their rebuild.

title: Making movies, like making sausages, is not pretty. Just ask John Sayles.
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: John Sayles discusses his latest novel 'Crucible', set in historical Detroit during Prohibition and Henry Ford's era.
Sayles turns to novel writing due to the challenges of funding films, using stories that expand beyond a screenplay format.
Upcoming Sayles events in Massachusetts include appearances in Cambridge, Plymouth, and Newburyport from February 10 to 14, 2026.

title: Can you find your partner on a stoop in Southie? The creator of Boston’s ‘Stoop Dating’ thinks so.
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Stoop Dating, a Boston-based dating show on social media, has over 30,000 followers on Instagram and 44,300 on TikTok.
Creator Julz Radley launched the show to promote face-to-face interactions in the Boston dating scene, filming on a Southie porch step.
The selection process involves choosing male participants first due to a larger pool of female applicants; same-sex dates are also matched.

title: 2 charged in Brockton killing after months as fugitives, DA says
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Micheal Thompson, 35, and Dayana Slade, 25, were arrested in Maine for the fatal shooting of Mike Jonas in Brockton.
Thompson is charged with first-degree murder; Slade is charged as an accessory and held on $250,000 bail.
Jonas was killed on September 23, 2025, in Finnegan Park, Brockton; Thompson allegedly fled with Slade after the shooting.

title: Red Sox reportedly tried to trade for standout shortstop this offseason
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox explored trading for Angels shortstop Zach Neto this offseason but couldn't meet the high return demands.
Zach Neto, known for his defensive skills and 49 homers over two seasons, remains under contract with the Angels.
The Red Sox acquired Caleb Durbin from the Brewers and expect him to play third base, solidifying their infield lineup.

title: Former driving school owner gets 1 day in jail for RMV bribery scheme
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Carlos Cardosa, 72, former driving school owner, sentenced to one day in jail for bribery at Brockton RMV.
Cardosa paid $20,000 over 18 months for falsified road test results for 100-300 applicants from 2019 to 2021.
Cardosa's sentence reduced due to health issues from a 2022 attack; faces six months home incarceration, $5,500 fine.

title: Stefon Diggs and Cardi B may have broken up following Patriots Super Bowl loss
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Stefon Diggs and Cardi B reportedly ended their relationship after unfollowing each other on Instagram post-Super Bowl LX.
Stefon Diggs faced charges of strangulation, suffocation, and assault; arraignment is scheduled for February 13.
Cardi B and Diggs welcomed a baby boy in November, Cardi's fourth child and Diggs' third.

title: An emotional Alex Cora explains why Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl performance meant so much to him
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox manager Alex Cora found Bad Bunny's Super Bowl performance deeply meaningful, praising the artist for representing Puerto Rico and America.
Bad Bunny's halftime show marked the first full Spanish-language Super Bowl performance, receiving both support from Roger Goodell and criticism from Donald Trump.
Cora admired Bad Bunny for incorporating Puerto Rican cultural elements into the show and conveying a message of unity and love.
